findings.title: Skill does not specify a license
findings.description: Skill manifest does not include a 'license' field. Specifying a license helps users understand usage terms.
findings.remediation: Add 'license' field to SKILL.md frontmatter (e.g., MIT, Apache-2.0)

findings.title: CREDENTIAL HARVESTING detected by YARA
findings.description: Detects potential exposure of sensitive information like API keys, passwords, tokens, and certificates: export TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY
findings.remediation: Review and remove credential harvesting pattern

findings.title: API Key Required Without Security Guidance
findings.description: The skill requires TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY environment variable but provides no security guidance on key protection, rotation, or scope limitations. Users are instructed to store the key in ~/.zshenv which persists it in plaintext. No warnings about key exposure risks or best practices for credential management.
findings.remediation: Add security warnings about: (1) Not committing keys to version control, (2) Using restricted-scope API keys if available, (3) Regular key rotation, (4) Risks of plaintext storage in shell config files. Consider recommending more secure credential storage methods.

metadata.overall_assessment: The youtube-playlist skill is a relatively safe wrapper around the TranscriptAPI.com service for browsing YouTube playlists and fetching transcripts. The skill uses only Bash curl commands to interact with an external API and does not contain executable scripts, prompt injection attempts, or data exfiltration code. The primary security concerns are: (1) API key management lacks security guidance, instructing users to store credentials in plaintext shell config files without warnings about exposure risks, (2) Missing optional manifest metadata reduces transparency about operational scope, and (3) Documentation references non-existent files. No critical threats were identified - the skill does not attempt to override instructions, exfiltrate data beyond its stated purpose, or execute malicious code. The external API dependency is clearly documented and matches the skill's stated purpose.

findings.title: Missing Optional Metadata Fields
findings.description: The skill manifest is missing optional fields that help users understand security boundaries: 'allowed-tools' (which agent tools can be used), 'compatibility' (environment requirements), and 'license' (usage terms). While these are optional per the spec, their absence reduces transparency about the skill's operational scope.
findings.snippet: allowed-tools: Not specified, compatibility: Not specified, license: Not specified
findings.remediation: Add optional manifest fields: (1) allowed-tools: [Bash] to indicate only Bash tool usage, (2) compatibility: Specify supported environments, (3) license: Add appropriate open source license. This improves transparency and helps users understand security boundaries.

No critical threats were identified - the skill does not attempt to override instructions, exfiltrate data beyond its stated purpose, or execute malicious code. findings.title: Referenced Files Not Found in Package
findings.description: The skill instructions reference files 'a.py' and 'URL.py' that are not present in the skill package. These appear to be documentation artifacts or errors rather than actual dependencies, but their presence in the reference list could confuse users or indicate incomplete packaging.
findings.snippet: Files referenced in instructions: a.py, URL.py (both not found)
findings.remediation: Remove references to non-existent files from the documentation, or include the files if they are intended to be part of the skill package. Ensure all referenced files are present and documented.
